prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 CO J=1-0
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Main focus science goal: Constrain the size of the emitting region of the CO J=1-0 line with the use of the 12m-array and the ACA. Requires high sensitivity to detect weak emission in the outer, tenuous wind and trace the transition region between the high and low mass-loss-rate components. This line is predicted to be affected the most by introducing a discontinuity in the mass-loss history at ~10^3 years. In this case, a significant fraction of its line formation occurs much closer to the stellar surface than in the case where the high mass-loss rate has been ongoing for 10^4 years. CO J=1-0 is expected to form in a very extended region, especially in the tenuous outer wind, and therefore requires complementary ACA observations.
Dust flux density is estimated to be low, but still detectable with the requested sensitivity. Dust is not the main focus for this science goal, but its detection will still provide a good constraint on the slope of the SED at mm wavelengths. Two continuum spectral basebands are included in the correlator setup to measure dust specifically.
Additional science is provided by the baseband focused on the C17O J=1-0 emission line. This line has not been detected before and is predicted to be very weak. Given that the requested sensitivity is entirely driven by detecting the weaker emission from the main CO isopotologue in the tenuous outer wind, the deep integration will give an upper limit for the emission expected from the C17O and as such provide a lower limit on the 16O/17O ratio. This is useful for constraining nucleosynthetic models, especially considering OH30.1-0.7 has shown the signs of hot-bottom burning where 17O is significantly enhanced with respect to 18O.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- Imaging requirements: In the long-superwind case, the CO J=1-0 line is expected to form primarily in the outer regions of the wind. This very extended region will be too large for the 12m array to resolve, so we request parallel ACA observations to ensure we probe the whole CO J=1-0 region.
In the short-superwind case, the CO J=1-0 line is expected to form primarily around where the transition from low to high mass-loss rate occurs. Where this transition occurs is strongly model dependent, requiring us to ask for both highly resolved observations as well as to resolve the larger-scale stucture. This way we ensure we will detect the transition region and constrain the size of the wind.
The outer wind is likely very weak. However, even a weak detection allows us to apply our modeling approach based on the line contribution regions showcased in Fig. 2 of the science case, because this approach weights the emission with R^2.
- Correlator setup: The main focus is the CO J=1-0 line. Our sensitivity calculations, and baseband placement are based entirely around this line. We include the C17O J=1-0 line as well, to provide a lower limit on the 16O/17O isotopic ratio. Two continuum basebands are included to measure the weaker dust emission.
The chosen bandwidths and spectral resolution are such that the CO lines are well resolved. The CO lines have a FWHM of 36 km/s, based on the CO expansion velocity of 18 km/s. The requested spectral resolution of 2.6 km/s provides about 10 data points in the line profile. This is sufficient, given that we do not expect any complex line profiles.
- Sensitivity requested: The expected peak flux density of the line at 0.25 Jy/beam is estimated from a 3D radiative-transfer model which has been processed through the OST. We request a sensitivity of 0.01 Jy which leads to a high SNR of 25, which will allow us to detect the weaker emission in the outer, tenuous wind as well. The weakest CO emission near the photodissociation radius will likely not be detected by the 12m array (due to being too extended or too weak), but the ACA will be able to still detect this weak component at the given sensitivity. Detecting the emission in the outer wind puts an important constraint on the low-mass-loss-rate component of the mass-loss history.
The requested sensitivity leads to an expected continuum RMS of 140 microJy. The expected peak flux density is 0.002 Jy/beam, well above the detection limit, assuming that the ACA detects the tenuous outer dust wind as well. The requested sensitivity for the CO line is sufficient for the dust continuum as well, yet this detection provides a strong constraint for the long-wavelength slope in the SED along with the two other requested science goals.
Note that the source is located in the galactic plane where a lot of diffuse background emission can contaminate observations. ALMA is expected not to suffer from this, due to the large-scale structure inherent to this diffuse background, allowing ALMA to place strong constraints on dust contribution without background confusion.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 CO J=3-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Main focus science goal: Constrain the size of the emitting region of the CO J=3-2 line with the use of the 12m-array. Requires high sensitivity to detect the transition region between the high and low mass-loss-rate components. The CO J=3-2 emission is expected to be sensitive to where the transition from low to high mass-loss rate happens. Due to specific location of the line contribution region of this line, the ACA will not be needed.
The dust continuum provides an additional point in the long-wavelength slope of the SED and therefore helps to constrain the presence/need of large, cold grains in the wind.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- Imaging requirements: In both the long-superwind case and the short-superwind case, the CO J=3-2 line is expected to form primarily around 2000-4000 AU, making this line very sensitive to the size of the superwind. We therefore focus on this line with the 12m array, and do not require the ACA as there is no extended emission expected for this line. Instead, we have tuned the maximum resolution such that we still resolve the line contribution zone of the J=3-2 line, but not more. This allows for detectability of somewhat larger-scale strucure as well, precluding the need for the ACA.
- Correlator setup: The main focus is the CO J=3-2 line. Our sensitivity calculations, and baseband placement are based entirely around this line. We include the 29SiO line as well, but it is expected to be weak. The continuum in this baseband is useful, regardless, but if the 29SiO line is detected, this can provide input constraints for future proposals on this source. Two continuum basebands are included to measure the dust emission.
The chosen bandwidths and spectral resolution are such that the CO lines are well resolved. The CO lines have a FWHM of 36 km/s, based on the CO expansion velocity of 18 km/s. The requested spectral resolution of 0.85 km/s provides about 40 data points in the line profile. This is sufficient, and will even resolve any substrucure that might be present, although we do not expect this.
- Sensitivity requested: The expected peak flux density of the line at 0.8 Jy/beam is estimated from a 3D radiative-transfer model which has been processed through the OST. We request a sensitivity of 0.01 Jy which leads to an SNR of 80, very high for the peak flux density. However, owing to the dominant line contribution region of the CO J=3-2 line being located around where the transition from low to high mass-loss rate is expected, this is the ideal tracer line. The high requested SNR therefore allows to probe more accurately the spatial distribution of the CO emission, and produce images such as those in Fig. 2 in the science case with very high accuracy. This way we can constrain where the transition region from low to high mass-loss rate is located, if it does indeed exist.
The requested sensitivity leads to an expected continuum RMS of 120 microJy. The expected peak flux density is 0.01 Jy/beam, which is well above the detection limit, but the lack of ACA observations in this setting will cause us to lose some flux. The high requested SNR in this setting counterbalances this, however, allowing us still to detect the dust contribution at this wavelength and help constrain the long-wavelength slope in the SED.
Note that the source is located in the galactic plane where a lot of diffuse background emission can contaminate observations. ALMA is expected not to suffer from this, due to the large-scale structure inherent to this diffuse background, allowing ALMA to place strong constraints on dust contribution without background confusion.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 9 CO J=6-5
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The highest-excitation CO line available with ALMA is the J=6-5. The line is excited around 1000 AU from the stellar surface. This line is thus expected to be exclusively formed in the superwind and allows us to constrain the high mass-loss rate. Additionally, it can be directly compared to other, spatially unresolved lines observed with different observatories.
This is our calibrator line for the lower-J emission lines, which may be affected by the transition region between the high and low mass-loss rate regime.
Importantly, the dust emission from the envelope will be the brightest in this band. Therefore, we request the most extended possible setup to acquire the best available spatial resolution, while also still resolving the largest-scale structure possible with the ACA with a single pointing. This will be a hard constraint on the size of the dusty wind and will provide insight in the presence of large grains throughout the wind.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- Imaging requirements: The requested resolution is primarily driven by the expected small-scale emission from the CO J=6-5 line, and the need to resolve where the dust is emitting in the envelope.
The largest-scale structure still possible to be observed with the ACA is requested. With an expected continuum flux density per beam of 1 Jy, dust emission will be brightest in Band 9, which makes dust far out in the tenuous wind accessible. Regardless of the size of the dusty wind, we are able to constrain it with this setup.
The smallest-scale structure still possible to be observed with the 12m-array is requested. The CO J=6-5 forms in the intermediate wind, around 500-1000 AU. High resolving power is needed to trace the line formation region for this transition, similar to the images shown in Figure 2 in the science case.
Additionally, this high-resolution image can be compared to the MIDI VLTI visibilities of this source, which provides a strong constraint of the dust component in the INNER wind. MIDI VLTI has a higher sensitivity to small dust grains, while ALMA will be more sensitive to large dust grains. The combination of the two powerful interferometers will allow us to discern between small and large dust grains, the third and final objective of this proposal.
- Correlator setup: The main focus is the CO J=6-5 line and the dust continuum. Our sensitivity calculations, and baseband placement are based entirely around the CO line. The additional basebands are attributed a broad bandwidth for optimal continuum detection, given that dust will be brightest in this ALMA band. We placed molecular lines of interest (SiO, 30SiO, C17O) in these bands, such that if they are detected at low spectral resolution, they can provide input for follow-up observations.
The chosen bandwidth and spectral resolution resolves the CO line well. The CO line has a FWHM of 36 km/s, based on the CO expansion velocity of 18 km/s. The requested spectral resolution of 0.42 km/s provides about 80 data points in the line profile. This is more than sufficient, and allows to rebin the data by a factor of ten, thereby improving the SNR.
- Sensitivity requested: The expected peak flux density of the line at 0.25 Jy/beam is estimated from a 3D radiative-transfer model which has been processed through the OST. We request a sensitivity of 0.05 Jy which leads to an SNR of 5. Given that we can rebin these data by a factor of 10 and still maintain the required spectral resolution, this leads to an effective SNR of ~15. This is significantly lower than what we request for the CO J=3-2, but we do not require the CO J=6-5 to be as sensitively detected, as it does not trace the transition region from low to high mass-loss rate. The CO J=6-5 line will probe the spatial distribution of the CO emission to produce images such as those in Fig. 2 in the science case, also thanks to the ACA. As such, the CO J=6-5 provides a reliable tracer of the high mass-loss-rate regime, which must then be evaluated with the lower-J CO lines, that are predicted not to follow this high mass-loss-rate trend.
The requested sensitivity leads to an expected continuum RMS of 0.5 mJy. The expected peak flux density is 1 Jy/beam, which is well above the detection limit. The specific request for high spatial resolution as well as detecting the larger scale structure also benefits from the high sensitivity, ensuring that we trace the dust throughout the whole wind. The dust continuum in this band provides the strongest constraint on the long-wavelength slope of the SED.
Note that the source is located in the galactic plane where a lot of diffuse background emission can contaminate observations. ALMA is expected not to suffer from this, due to the large-scale structure inherent to this diffuse background, allowing ALMA to place strong constraints on dust contribution without background confusion.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Our understanding of the late stages of evolution of 5-8 solar-mass stars on the asymptotic giant branch has been challenged. A high mass-loss-rate superwind of several 10^-4 solar masses per year has long been suggested to allow these stars to evolve into white dwarfs. However, results published in 2013 show that this superwind lasts no longer than a thousand years. This implies that these stars need to lose several solar masses by means other than one superwind.
We propose a pilot study to confirm the short-superwind model for the OH/IR star OH30.1-0.7. By measuring the CO formation regions we can constrain the mass-loss history of OH30.1-0.7. The high sensitivity required to map the CO emission also allows a direct measurement of the dust continuum. We aim to constrain the size of the CO as well as the dusty stellar wind, in order to validate or falsify the current theory that this star recently started its superwind. ALMA's unprecedented sensitivity and spatial resolution are key to pin down the size of the superwind.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: The onset of superwind in OH 26.5+0.6: the last stage of mass loss in intermediate-mass AGB stars (PI: K. Justtanont)
